definition: to balance up/to offset/to counterbalance
appearance/portrait/picture/government minister/(physics) phase/(literary) to appraise (esp. by scrutinizing physical features)/to read sb's fortune (by physiognomy, palmistry etc)
each other/one another/mutually/fret on the neck of a pipa 琵琶[pi2 pa5] (a fret on the soundboard is called a 品[pin3])
surname Xiang
to press against/to support/to prop up/to resist/to equal/to balance/to make up for/to mortgage/to arrive at/to clap (one's hands) lightly (expressing delight) (Taiwan pr. [zhi3] for this sense)
to break even/balance between income and expenditure

sentences.english: We should not compare with the higher. Otherwise, we won't make both ends meet.
sentences.chinese: 我們不應與人攀比，否則就無法收支相抵。

sentences.english: The accounts show a favourable balance of 150 yuan.
The tradesman balanced his losses against his profits.
sentences.chinese: 那商人把他的虧損跟贏利相抵。

sentences.english: We wish that the figures for income and costs balance out.
sentences.chinese: 我們希望收入和花費的數字正好相抵。

sentences.english: After six months of trading the company broke even.
sentences.chinese: 在經營了六個月後，公司已收支相抵。

sentences.english: On paper, the bills break even for the budget.
sentences.chinese: 在紙面上，議案的預算收支相抵。

sentences.english: Gains and losses average out to a large profit each month.
sentences.chinese: 每月得失相抵仍有許多賺頭。

sentences.english: The caller is having a tough time right now making ends meet.
sentences.chinese: 這位打電話的人現在正苦於讓收支相抵。

sentences.english: They have difficulty in making both ends meet.
sentences.chinese: 他們要做到收支相抵很困難。

definition: both sides
two-phase (physics)
to disregard/to reject
variant of 拼[pin1]
hedging (finance)
to intertwine/to intermingle
to resist/to press against/to brace
to press against/to support/to prop up/to resist/to equal/to balance/to make up for/to mortgage/to arrive at/to clap (one's hands) lightly (expressing delight) (Taiwan pr. [zhi3] for this sense)
lit. to turn over one's palm/fig. everything is going very well.
to disregard/to take no account of
(literary) to eliminate/to put an end to
to conform to/to fit with/to be compatible with
to merge together (idiom); to unify disparate elements into one whole
bad luck/unlucky fate
lit. as close as lips and teeth (idiom); closely related/interdependent
to collide/collision
to spread out/(fig.) to share equally
to cross over (e.g. traffic)/to intersect/to make friends
